commit_message:
provide a replacement for the deprecated isotime()

This change proposes a new timeutils.isoformat() to replace the earlier
one which was deprecated.

Several issues with the old isotime() function became apparent in
reviewing the steps required to handle the deprecation of
isotime(). These are detailed in the bug 1592181.

I strongly urge all reviewers to read the bug (referenced) and the
comments as part of the review.

WARNING: This code as proposed could introduce inconsistencies in the
way in which the earlier isotime() returns results. Specifically,
these two situations are known.

1. If you provide a timestamp that includes timezone information, the
old isotime() would wilfully ignore it, the new isoformat() function
will produce offset information in the resulting string. If the
timezone is UTC, you will get the 'Z' suffix, if it is non-UTC, you
will get the full 6 character offset +/-hh:mm.

2. If you provided isotime() with the subsecond parameter it returned
the (im)PERFECT_TIMESTAMP_FORMAT which included subsecond information
but NO timezone information. The new isoformat() returns timezone
information. If the timezone is UTC, you will get the 'Z' suffix, if
it is non-UTC, you will get the full 6 character offset +/-hh:mm.

In addition, a behavior which makes this implementation of isoformat()
differ from the original is that if you provide isoformat() with a
timestamp that includes invalid timezone information (such as an
offset greater than one day) then isoformat() will throw a
ValueError. The old isotime() was wilfully unaware and you wouldn't
get such an exception.

Tests have been proposed which exercise the new isoformat() function.

The term "wilfully unaware" that I use in the description above is
non-standard. It is not the same as 'naive'. Rather, 'wilfully
unaware' indicates code that knowingly treats timestamps as naive
without checking or making any consideration for whether they are
aware or naive.

I believe that this code, warts and all is better than having multiple
buggy copies of isotime() in each project; each just slightly
different from the other to make your skin crawl. It is generally
advisable when you have bad apples, to put them all together and away
from the good ones. This change attempts to do that.

Change-Id: Ifb367a1f96a663a1d54b1770b9d20bbffdba491c
Related: Ic5abf6669edd4f1a9fd62e61f437565aa887aebe
Closes-Bug: #1592181
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo.utils refs/changes/84/329384/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: class bogus_tzinfo(datetime.tzinfo): """A bogus tzinfo class""" def utcoffset(self, dt): return datetime.timedelta(hours=2) def tzname(self, dt): return "BOGUS" def dst(self, dt): return datetime.timedelta(hours=1) class invalid_tzinfo(datetime.tzinfo): """An invalid tzinfo class to provoke an error""" def utcoffset(self, dt): return datetime.timedelta(hours=25) def tzname(self, dt): return "INVALID" def dst(self, dt): return datetime.timedelta(hours=25) def test_utcnow_tz(self): dt = timeutils.utcnow() self.assertEqual(None, dt.tzinfo) def test_utcnow_aware_tz(self): dt = timeutils.utcnow_aware() self.assertEqual(datetime.timedelta(0), dt.utcoffset()) self.assertEqual('UTC', dt.tzname()) def test_isotime(self): dt = timeutils.utcnow_aware() expected = "%04d-%02d-%02dT%02d:%02d:%02dZ" % ( dt.year, dt.month, dt.day, dt.hour, dt.minute, dt.second) self.assertEqual(expected, timeutils.isotime(dt)) def test_isotime_subsecond(self): dt = timeutils.utcnow_aware() expected = "%04d-%02d-%02dT%02d:%02d:%02d.%06dZ" % ( dt.year, dt.month, dt.day, dt.hour, dt.minute, dt.second, dt.microsecond) self.assertEqual(expected, timeutils.isotime(dt, subsecond=True)) def test_isotime_unaware(self): dt = timeutils.utcnow() expected = "%04d-%02d-%02dT%02d:%02d:%02d.%06dZ" % ( dt.year, dt.month, dt.day, dt.hour, dt.minute, dt.second, dt.microsecond) self.assertEqual(expected, timeutils.isotime(dt, subsecond=True)) def test_isotime_unaware_subsecond(self): dt = timeutils.utcnow() expected = "%04d-%02d-%02dT%02d:%02d:%02d.%06dZ" % ( dt.year, dt.month, dt.day, dt.hour, dt.minute, dt.second, dt.microsecond) self.assertEqual(expected, timeutils.isotime(dt, subsecond=True)) def test_bogus_unaware(self): dt = datetime.datetime.now(bogus_tzinfo()) expected = "%04d-%02d-%02dT%02d:%02d:%02d.%06d+02:00" % ( dt.year, dt.month, dt.day, dt.hour, dt.minute, dt.second, dt.microsecond) self.assertEqual(expected, timeutils.isotime(dt, subsecond=True)) def test_bogus_unaware_subsecond(self): dt = datetime.datetime.now(bogus_tzinfo()) expected = "%04d-%02d-%02dT%02d:%02d:%02d.%06d+02:00" % ( dt.year, dt.month, dt.day, dt.hour, dt.minute, dt.second, dt.microsecond) self.assertEqual(expected, timeutils.isotime(dt, subsecond=True)) def test_throws_exception(self): dt = datetime.datetime.now() dt = dt.replace(tzinfo=invalid_tzinfo()) self.assertRaises(ValueError, timeutils.isotime, dt)
deleted_lines: def test_isotime(self): with mock.patch('datetime.datetime') as datetime_mock: datetime_mock.utcnow.return_value = self.skynet_self_aware_time dt = timeutils.isotime() self.assertEqual(dt, self.skynet_self_aware_time_str) def test_isotimei_micro_second_precision(self): with mock.patch('datetime.datetime') as datetime_mock: datetime_mock.utcnow.return_value = self.skynet_self_aware_ms_time dt = timeutils.isotime(subsecond=True) self.assertEqual(dt, self.skynet_self_aware_time_ms_str)

commit_message:
Remove useless str()

This change uses:

  LOG.exception(_LE("... %s"), cmd)

instead of:

  LOG.exception(_LE("... %s"), str(cmd))

because %s converts python object using str.

Change-Id: I19c21f6e357f3cba3f5937f63a690628205d5e5b

commit_message:
Fix unwanted unmounting of /usr/share/oem

Creating specific partitions will cause a udev event to trigger,
causing systemd to attempt to mount the new partition at /usr/share/oem.

This mount will not succeed, but will unmount /usr/share/oem,
causing ironic-python-agent to die.

Masking this unit disables this behavior.

Change-Id: Ifea3482f36a354cbf988e6f6003f4284c5c2a21d
Closes-bug: #1592163
(cherry picked from commit da0a8aff88e67fce7603b03a220b77b451349e7d)

commit_message:
Correct DB modifications from compaction

There were a few minor differences in the compacted DB schema
causing problems in some situations. This changes some definitions
missed in the initial migration compaction.

Change-Id: I53451892732078e96b53d780d50f823802e5e03d
Closes-Bug: #1593175

subunit-trace is also provided by os-testr which
is a more lightweight dependency than tempest-lib.

commit_message:
Python 3: replace exec with six.exec_()

The "exec" statement was removed in Python 3. Replace it with
six.exec_() to add compatibility with Python 3.

Blueprint: murano-python-3-support
Change-Id: Idd1c6a6347e22f6a9c7887e7a327d29bb64e46d5

commit_message:
Support systemd on Fedora-based distros

Modify start_ceph and stop_ceph functions to use 'systemctl'
and ceph.target for Fedora and RHEL7 deployments with Infernalis
or later as specified in ceph release notes [1].

Also note that non-ubuntu systems may install from gitbuilder.

[1] http://docs.ceph.com/docs/master/release-notes/#upgrading-from-hammer

Change-Id: I45a1853d6c2dea11e83134c3134a890aed30a9cc
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/devstack-plugin-ceph refs/changes/95/313495/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # for their distro (if available) from download.ceph.com or # gitbuilder.ceph.com and then do stack.sh. if is_fedora || [[ $DISTRO == "rhel7" ]]; then sudo systemctl start ceph.target else sudo service ceph start fi if is_fedora || [[ $DISTRO == "rhel7" ]]; then sudo systemctl stop ceph.target else sudo service ceph stop > /dev/null 2>&1 fi
deleted_lines: # for their distro (if available) from download.ceph.com and then do # stack.sh sudo service ceph start sudo service ceph stop > /dev/null 2>&1

commit_message:
Modify influx port to avoid conflict

Moved an internal influx port to avoid conflict with zuul's
console log module

Add influx log to collected log files

commit_message:
Fix unwanted unmounting of /usr/share/oem

Creating specific partitions will cause a udev event to trigger,
causing systemd to attempt to mount the new partition at /usr/share/oem.

This mount will not succeed, but will unmount /usr/share/oem,
causing ironic-python-agent to die.

Masking this unit disables this behavior.

Change-Id: Ifea3482f36a354cbf988e6f6003f4284c5c2a21d
Closes-bug: #1592163
(cherry picked from commit da0a8aff88e67fce7603b03a220b77b451349e7d)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic-python-agent refs/changes/71/332471/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: - name: usr-share-oem.mount mask: true

commit_message:
Simplify boolean expression in executils.py

There's no need for checking again if next_up is not instance of
CausedByException as this is exactly what the else clause means.

Change-Id: I437b3b4948e89d6a138be03e9613e522b10d4824

subject: Fix an issue with oslo_config_project paste config
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-06-21 20:02:43.000000000', 'files': ['keystonemiddleware/_common/config.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/keystonemiddleware/commit/2798b2ebdf56a63ad1c20b3b0d7d2f0b1f1368a5', 'message': 'Fix an issue with oslo_config_project paste config

When oslo_config_project is specified in the paste config, we need to
lookup the configuration file properly. Commit
f8c150a9cc9b407b2df87244daf3342177260e90 changed the way we looked up
for the default config files, and passed an empty list instead of None,
which means that no look were done anymore. This restores the previous
behavior.

Change-Id: I6aec548cec24dfcd48e4c116c07f53cc097c6059
Closes-Bug: #1594930
'}]
commit_message:
Fix an issue with oslo_config_project paste config

When oslo_config_project is specified in the paste config, we need to
lookup the configuration file properly. Commit
f8c150a9cc9b407b2df87244daf3342177260e90 changed the way we looked up
for the default config files, and passed an empty list instead of None,
which means that no look were done anymore. This restores the previous
behavior.

Change-Id: I6aec548cec24dfcd48e4c116c07f53cc097c6059
Closes-Bug: #1594930

commit_message:
Add Tempest tests to validate checksum usage

This adds 2 new Tempest tests that verify checksum usage during backup
and restore. The first test, `test_freezer_fs_backup_valid_checksum`,
ensures that both backup and restore complete correctly with checksum
computation and validation enabled. The second test,
`test_freezer_fs_backup_bad_checksum`, verifies correct error behavior
when attempting to restore a backup with an invalid checksum.

Change-Id: I8a0a70bbe0c87c8f1ea1c8e013c443cac62cfc1e
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/freezer refs/changes/13/329113/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # (C) Copyright 2016 Hewlett Packard Enterprise Development Company LP # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. import json import os import shutil import subprocess import uuid from freezer.tests.freezer_tempest_plugin.tests.api import base from tempest import test BACKUP_BASE_DIR = '/tmp/freezer-test-backup-source' RESTORE_BASE_DIR = '/tmp/freezer-test-backup-restore' STORAGE_BASE_DIR = '/tmp/freezer-test-backup-local-storage' def touch(*path): """Create a new empty file at the given path. Given a series of path components, join them using :code:`os.path.join()`, open the corresponding file for writing, and immediately close it. The file will be created on disk but will be empty. :param path: The path (or series of paths) at which to create the new file. """ open(os.path.join(*path), 'w').close() class TestFreezerMetadataChecksum(base.BaseFreezerTest): def __init__(self, *args, **kwargs): super(TestFreezerMetadataChecksum, self).__init__(*args, **kwargs) # noinspection PyAttributeOutsideInit def setUp(self): super(TestFreezerMetadataChecksum, self).setUp() # compute scratch directories to use for the test test_id = uuid.uuid4().hex self.backup_source_dir = os.path.join(BACKUP_BASE_DIR, test_id) self.backup_source_sub_dir = os.path.join( self.backup_source_dir, 'subdir') self.restore_target_dir = os.path.join(RESTORE_BASE_DIR, test_id) self.backup_local_storage_dir = os.path.join(STORAGE_BASE_DIR, test_id) self.freezer_backup_name = 'freezer-test-backup-checksum-0' self.metadata_out = os.path.join( self.backup_local_storage_dir, self.freezer_backup_name + '.json') # clean up any previous test data and create empty directory structure shutil.rmtree(self.backup_source_dir, True) os.makedirs(self.backup_source_dir) os.makedirs(self.backup_source_sub_dir) shutil.rmtree(self.restore_target_dir, True) os.makedirs(self.restore_target_dir) shutil.rmtree(self.backup_local_storage_dir, True) os.makedirs(self.backup_local_storage_dir) # create a quick directory structure to back up for f in ['a', 'b', 'c']: touch(self.backup_source_dir, f) for f in ['x', 'y', 'z']: touch(self.backup_source_sub_dir, f) self.environ = super(TestFreezerMetadataChecksum, self).get_environ() def tearDown(self): super(TestFreezerMetadataChecksum, self).tearDown() shutil.rmtree(self.backup_source_dir, True) shutil.rmtree(self.restore_target_dir, True) shutil.rmtree(self.backup_local_storage_dir) @test.attr(type="gate") def test_freezer_fs_backup_valid_checksum(self): # perform a normal backup, but enable consistency checks and save the # metadata to disk backup_args = ['freezer-agent', '--path-to-backup', self.backup_source_dir, '--container', self.backup_local_storage_dir, '--backup-name', self.freezer_backup_name, '--storage', 'local', '--consistency_check', '--metadata-out', self.metadata_out] self.run_subprocess(backup_args, 'Test backup to local storage.') # load the stored metadata to retrieve the computed checksum with open(self.metadata_out) as f: metadata = json.load(f) self.assertIn('consistency_checksum', metadata, 'Checksum must exist in stored metadata.') checksum = metadata['consistency_checksum'] restore_args = ['freezer-agent', '--action', 'restore', '--restore-abs-path', self.restore_target_dir, '--container', self.backup_local_storage_dir, '--backup-name', self.freezer_backup_name, '--storage', 'local', '--consistency_checksum', checksum] self.run_subprocess(restore_args, 'Test restore from local storage with ' 'computed checksum.') @test.attr(type="gate") def test_freezer_fs_backup_bad_checksum(self): # as above, but we'll ignore the computed checksum backup_args = ['freezer-agent', '--path-to-backup', self.backup_source_dir, '--container', self.backup_local_storage_dir, '--backup-name', self.freezer_backup_name, '--storage', 'local', '--consistency_check', '--metadata-out', self.metadata_out] self.run_subprocess(backup_args, 'Test backup to local storage.') # make a failing sha256 checksum (assuming no added path string) bad_checksum = '0' * 64 # attempt to restore using the bad checksum restore_args = ['freezer-agent', '--action', 'restore', '--restore-abs-path', self.restore_target_dir, '--container', self.backup_local_storage_dir, '--backup-name', self.freezer_backup_name, '--storage', 'local', '--consistency_checksum', bad_checksum] process = subprocess.Popen(restore_args, stdout=subprocess.PIPE, stderr=subprocess.PIPE, env=self.environ, shell=False) out, err = process.communicate() # make sure the subprocess exist with an error due to checksum mismatch message = '{0} Output: {1} Error: {2}'.format( 'Restore process should fail with checksum error.', out, err) self.assertEqual(1, process.returncode, message) self.assertEqual('', out, message) self.assertNotEqual('', err, message)

commit_message:
Add unit tests in cinder for HPE Lefthand driver

This commit has unit tests for check_for_setup_error,
get_version_string and of _login, failover_host,
_do_volume_replication_destroy, _create_replication_client,
create_cgsnapshot and delete_cgsnapshot functions of ISCSI
HPE Lefthand driver

A bug fixed in delete_cgsnapshot function of hpe_lefthand_iscsi file.
Error log message has wrong syntax of printing 'error' dictionary-key.

Closes-bug: #1591040
Change-Id: I1efcf202eaddb5f39b119f0ea1a09fbf8b504e5a
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/48/317948/8 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def test_check_for_setup_error(self): # setup drive with default configuration # and return the mock HTTP LeftHand client mock_client = self.setup_driver() # test for latest version mock_client.getApiVersion.return_value = ('3.0.0') with mock.patch.object(hpe_lefthand_iscsi.HPELeftHandISCSIDriver, '_create_client') as mock_do_setup: mock_do_setup.return_value = mock_client # execute driver self.driver.check_for_setup_error() expected = self.driver_startup_call_stack + [ mock.call.getApiVersion(), mock.call.logout()] mock_client.assert_has_calls(expected) # test for older version mock_client.reset_mock() mock_client.getApiVersion.return_value = ('1.0.0') # execute driver self.driver.check_for_setup_error() mock_client.assert_has_calls(expected) # mock HTTPServerError (array failure) mock_client.createSnapshotSet.side_effect =\ hpeexceptions.HTTPServerError() # ensure the raised exception is a cinder exception self.assertRaises( exception.VolumeBackendAPIException, self.driver.create_cgsnapshot, ctxt, cgsnapshot, expected_snaps) # mock HTTPServerError (array failure) mock_client.getVolumeByName.side_effect =\ hpeexceptions.HTTPNotFound() # ensure the raised exception is a cinder exception self.assertRaises( exception.VolumeBackendAPIException, self.driver.create_cgsnapshot, ctxt, cgsnapshot, expected_snaps) # mock HTTPServerError ex = hpeexceptions.HTTPServerError({ 'message': 'Hey, dude cannot be deleted because it is a clone point' ' duh.'}) mock_client.getSnapshotByName.side_effect = ex # ensure the raised exception is a cinder exception cgsnap, snaps = self.driver.delete_cgsnapshot( ctxt, cgsnapshot, expected_snaps) self.assertEqual('error', snaps[0]['status']) # mock HTTP other errors ex = hpeexceptions.HTTPConflict({'message': 'Some message.'}) mock_client.getSnapshotByName.side_effect = ex # ensure the raised exception is a cinder exception cgsnap, snaps = self.driver.delete_cgsnapshot( ctxt, cgsnapshot, expected_snaps) self.assertEqual('error', snaps[0]['status'])

subject: Remove MAC duplicate detection for generated macs
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-06-08 23:31:34.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/039e09336f3d327139aed9591758cf5b53be0bee', 'message': 'Preemptive MAC dup detection with retry

The previous MAC duplicate detection code relied on catching a
DBDuplicateError the correct time which resulted in two problems.
First, the duplicate could have been caused by something else being
flushed to the database at the same time.
Second, the DBDuplicate may not occur at flush time if the conflict
happens due to two concurrent port creations and it will instead
happen at commit time.

This patch adjusts the logic to just preemptively query the DB for
a duplicate record to determine if there is a duplicate. If there
is a race, one of the commits will fail with an uncaught DBDuplicateError,
which will be converted to a RetryRequest to start the process
over. At this point a new MAC will be generated or in the case
that the MAC was specified it will query the DB, find the dup,
and raise the error.

Change-Id: Idf816c07198be3ce745252ac9aa9c4aad8f11910
Closes-Bug: #1590602
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2016-06-09 22:00:02.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/eabd667e562a39f2b13029b9c58e665f4452f164', 'message': 'Remove MAC duplicate detection for generated macs

The previous MAC duplicate detection code relied on catching a
DBDuplicateError the correct time which resulted in two problems.
First, the duplicate could have been caused by something else being
flushed to the database at the same time.
Second, the DBDuplicate may not occur at flush time if the conflict
happens due to two concurrent port creations and it will instead
happen at commit time.

This patch just dumps the DBDuplicate catch to allow the API layer
to retry the operation since MAC collisions on a network should be
extremely rare.

Change-Id: Idf816c07198be3ce745252ac9aa9c4aad8f11910
Closes-Bug: #1590602

commit_message:
Remove MAC duplicate detection for generated macs

The previous MAC duplicate detection code relied on catching a
DBDuplicateError the correct time which resulted in two problems.
First, the duplicate could have been caused by something else being
flushed to the database at the same time.
Second, the DBDuplicate may not occur at flush time if the conflict
happens due to two concurrent port creations and it will instead
happen at commit time.

This patch just dumps the DBDuplicate catch to allow the API layer
to retry the operation since MAC collisions on a network should be
extremely rare.

Closes-Bug: #1590602
Change-Id: Idf816c07198be3ce745252ac9aa9c4aad8f11910
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/13/327413/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if self._is_mac_in_use(context, network_id, mac_address): db_port = models_v2.Port(mac_address=mac_address, **port_data) context.session.add(db_port) return db_port
deleted_lines: try: # since this method could either be used within or outside the # transaction, use convenience method to avoid passing a flag with db_api.autonested_transaction(context.session): db_port = models_v2.Port(mac_address=mac_address, **port_data) context.session.add(db_port) return db_port except db_exc.DBDuplicateEntry:

subject: Fix improperly configured privsep
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-06-14 17:20:25.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/os-brick/commit/9c31c1533a41987eefbb97a07bed43089cac67e9', 'message': "WIP fix grenade upgrade tests

This patch changes how brick calls privsep.

When the cinder.conf and nova.conf aren't setup with the helper_command,
os-brick will fallback to using the putils.execute() with the root_helper
and run_as_root kwargs.   This effectively will fall back to running all
commands via rootwrap.  We have to do this for systems that run
Continuous Deployment and don't upgrade their conf files with the
privsep_osbrick section that includes the new helper_command.

Change-Id: Id2fd3372aa50f1b8c9fa693baaf467776189e6ea

commit_message:
Fix improperly configured privsep

This patch changes how brick determines how to execute commands
in the system either using privsep or processutils.

When the cinder.conf and nova.conf aren't setup with the helper_command,
os-brick will fallback to using the putils.execute() with the root_helper
and run_as_root kwargs.   This effectively will fall back to running all
commands via rootwrap.  We have to do this for systems that run
Continuous Deployment and don't upgrade their conf files with the
privsep_osbrick section that includes the new helper_command.

With this patch os_brick won't use privesep unless the helper_command
is defined in the conf section labeled 'privsep_osbrick'

Change-Id: Id2fd3372aa50f1b8c9fa693baaf467776189e6ea
Closes-Bug: #1592043
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/os-brick refs/changes/86/329586/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from os_brick import privileged def is_privsep_enabled(): """Check to see if we will execute via privsep.""" conf = privileged.default.conf return ('helper_command' in conf and conf['helper_command'])

commit_message:
Improve unit tests for stack-update-cancel

There's little point in having a unit test that mirrors the logic of the
function it is testing, so refactor to assert the behaviour we want
explicitly. Also, add a test for a missing case.

In addition, the test_update_rollback_on_cancel_event test should have
changed the message from 'cancel' to 'cancel_with_rollback' in the patch
b76f6ec0e97a9c3aaf5b5140e7a449c9636b8f95, but this was inadvertently
omitted.

Change-Id: I70e51255ffd1e7f92d060c8da075f4ce4c506079

commit_message:
Fix argument order for assertEqual to (expected, observed)

assertEqual expects that the arguments provided to it should be
(expected, observed). If a particluar order is kept as a convention,
then it helps to provide a cleaner message to the developer if Unit
Tests fail. The following patch fixes this issue.

TrivialFix

Change-Id: I07b78383ef38731140143c91ae3a902bea55eebb
Closes-Bug: #1259292

commit_message:
Remove enable_tunneling config from openvswitch_agent.ini

There is no evidence that the config is used in either:
http://docs.openstack.org/mitaka/config-reference/networking/sample-configuration-files.html
or
http://docs.openstack.org/mitaka/networking-guide/scenario-dvr-ovs.html
or
https://github.com/openstack/neutron/search?utf8=%E2%9C%93&q=enable_tunneling

Rather, it appears that neutron manages this setting on the agent internally.

Change-Id: I23e544dd11f67061e18ddde5b5c70d10aa74e8ad
Implements: blueprint support-openvswitch
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-os_neutron refs/changes/57/332157/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
go: quarantine invalid files when replicating

The replicator parses object metadata and performs a metadata-only audit
before it replicates files.  This change makes it so that the replicator
will quarantine objects that fail validation.

Change-Id: I16d46c463482872af850cfe3b75053dd6db04d7b

commit_message:
VMware: Fix bug of TypeError when getting reference of VCenter cluster is None.

* When get VCenter of all cluster reference and return None, it's  a
  NoneType, and could not be iterable, so it will cause error like
  ：“TypeError: 'NoneType' object is not iterable ”.

* This patch add the situation of cluster reference is None, and will
  return an empyt list.

Closes-Bug: #1525913
Change-Id: Ifcf0e1edf378f239030a27e40d5bed436876858b
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/74/257674/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Break apart user scenario tests

The user actions group scenario tests were broken into separate parts
to facilitate parallel runs in the gate.

Initialized instance delete action was also broken down into
delete call itself and the wait for it to finish.

Change-Id: I651219cc1a5dae36d6001548bb6c9ea518cbce97
Partial-Bug: 1571092

commit_message:
Add group functional tests

Adds functional tests for groups. For now, the tests are created under
a single class. Once we have a gate that runs against LDAP,
we will create a class that only contains readonly tests and
a tox call for it (e.g tox -e functional-readonly).

Change-Id: Ib1db14367b8dc3bd6356aff0dfef1fc573211c6e
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-keystoneclient refs/changes/11/332411/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. import uuid from keystoneauth1.exceptions import http from keystoneclient.tests.functional import base from keystoneclient.tests.functional.v3 import client_fixtures as fixtures class GroupsTestCase(base.V3ClientTestCase): def check_group(self, group, group_ref=None): self.assertIsNotNone(group.id) self.assertIn('self', group.links) self.assertIn('/groups/' + group.id, group.links['self']) if group_ref: self.assertEqual(group_ref['name'], group.name) self.assertEqual(group_ref['domain'], group.domain_id) # There is no guarantee description is present in group if hasattr(group_ref, 'description'): self.assertEqual(group_ref['description'], group.description) else: # Only check remaining mandatory attributes self.assertIsNotNone(group.name) self.assertIsNotNone(group.domain_id) def test_create_group(self): group_ref = { 'name': fixtures.RESOURCE_NAME_PREFIX + uuid.uuid4().hex, 'domain': self.project_domain_id, 'description': uuid.uuid4().hex} group = self.client.groups.create(**group_ref) self.addCleanup(self.client.groups.delete, group) self.check_group(group, group_ref) def test_get_group(self): group = fixtures.Group(self.client, self.project_domain_id) self.useFixture(group) group_ret = self.client.groups.get(group.id) self.check_group(group_ret, group.ref) def test_list_groups(self): group_one = fixtures.Group(self.client, self.project_domain_id) self.useFixture(group_one) group_two = fixtures.Group(self.client, self.project_domain_id) self.useFixture(group_two) groups = self.client.groups.list() # All groups are valid for group in groups: self.check_group(group) self.assertIn(group_one.entity, groups) self.assertIn(group_two.entity, groups) def test_update_group(self): group = fixtures.Group(self.client, self.project_domain_id) self.useFixture(group) new_name = fixtures.RESOURCE_NAME_PREFIX + uuid.uuid4().hex new_description = uuid.uuid4().hex group_ret = self.client.groups.update(group.id, name=new_name, description=new_description) group.ref.update({'name': new_name, 'description': new_description}) self.check_group(group_ret, group.ref) def test_delete_group(self): group = self.client.groups.create(name=uuid.uuid4().hex, domain=self.project_domain_id) self.client.groups.delete(group.id) self.assertRaises(http.NotFound, self.client.groups.get, group.id)

commit_message:
Revert "Authorize super admin actions on all projects"

This reverts commit ac86702172ddf01f5bdc3f3cd99d2e32ad9b7024.

The switch to checking for is_admin_project on the auth token for
context_is_admin, makes heat unusable in a TripleO deployed
overcloud. I discussed with Adam Young from the Keystone team, and
he advised a revert until the issue is resolved in oslo.context[0].

[0] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/295870/

Conflicts:
	heat_integrationtests/functional/test_encryption_vol_type.py

Change-Id: Id5bde5413109b1ee1dac95deeb78e7fb528a5b18
Related-Bug: 1532427

subject: Pass input_values when creating SoftwareDeployment resources
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-06-17 07:10:28.000000000', 'files': ['heat/engine/resources/openstack/heat/software_deployment.py', 'heat/tests/openstack/heat/test_software_deployment.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/heat/commit/a3678ae17cadde391a10f702f9cbc4527907c88e', 'message': "Pass input_values when creating SoftwareDeployment resources

Currently we only store input_values via the derived config, we don't
pass it at all to the RPC API that creates the deployment, thus it gets
defaulted to {}.  Because the derived config inputs are correctly set,
this doesn't break the deployment/config operation, but it does lead to
some misleading empty input_values in the deployment-show CLI output.

Change-Id: Icad0f66a39de1ce5faec484aa0f34958167c9734
Closes-Bug: #1592588
(cherry picked from commit 5d999363952a14336ba72f16f85030019d32e55e)
"}]
commit_message:
Pass input_values when creating SoftwareDeployment resources

Currently we only store input_values via the derived config, we don't
pass it at all to the RPC API that creates the deployment, thus it gets
defaulted to {}.  Because the derived config inputs are correctly set,
this doesn't break the deployment/config operation, but it does lead to
some misleading empty input_values in the deployment-show CLI output.

Change-Id: Icad0f66a39de1ce5faec484aa0f34958167c9734
Closes-Bug: #1592588
(cherry picked from commit 5d999363952a14336ba72f16f85030019d32e55e)

commit_message:
Agent schedulers: do not use deprecated method

The method add_agent_status_check is deprecated we should now
be using add_agent_status_check_worker.

Change-Id: I5aa906b808939259732be81e1b36dd357e59d599
Closes-bug: #1591111

commit_message:
Ensure consistent naming of sample scenarios

Rename sample scenario files so that dash(-) used consistently
instead of underscore (_)

Change-Id: I8e4ccabfc16b32a12a091e6b168b12d25643b028

commit_message:
Break apart root scenario tests

The root actions group scenario tests were broken into separate parts
to facilitate parallel runs in the gate.

Change-Id: I63e995a2eda71183ef742d1091e7e871b53458a9
Partial-Bug: 1571092

commit_message:
api-ref: console types.

Documentation change in api-ref.

type is added to the parameter lists of Get RDP console, Get serial console,
Get SPICE console, Get VNC console.

Closes-Bug: 1587117
Closes-Bug: 1587118
Closes-Bug: 1587119
Closes-Bug: 1587121

Change-Id: I73823fd6fb0886e2fff0da4838fe868f578bba6d
Signed-off-by: csatari <gergely.csatari@nokia.com>

commit_message:
a depth in `get topology show` API can only be used
if there is a root

using vitrage in env without any root graph, unable to request
topology of type graph. A depth in `get topology show` API can
only be used if there is a root.

Fixes: bug #1586249

Change-Id: If59e7b60e9d31b5cfa1890a83269fbb04c97d385
Signed-off-by: dongwenjuan <dong.wenjuan@zte.com.cn>

revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-05-18 20:26:36.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/commit/242362317bd1fd9e95a7b5da0dd1079c649ac761', 'message': 'Remove excess database calls in volume attach

follow remove some of the unecessary calls being made. In a few spots,
simply moving the database calls into the proper paths helps eliminate
the excess cycles. In others, the require_volume_exists wrapper is
being used on a few methods that only get called inside of a method
which itself is wrapped with require_volume_exists. Removing these
wrappers eliminates the redundant call each time the method is used.

method to accept an attachment as an argument saves us another call
down that path if the information has already been queried prior.

commit_message:
Remove excess database calls in volume attach

In the volume attach flow there are currently a few spots where
unnecessary database calls are being performed. The changes that
follow remove some of the unecessary calls being made. In a few spots,
simply moving the database calls into the proper paths helps eliminate
the excess cycles. In others, the require_volume_exists wrapper is
being used on a few methods that only get called inside of a method
which itself is wrapped with require_volume_exists. Removing these
wrappers eliminates the redundant call each time the method is used.
In the last case, an optimization of the notify_about_volume_usage
method to accept an attachment as an argument saves us another call
down that path if the information has already been queried prior.

Change-Id: I54d356f2ade197bd91242ac8b66226f9e9841108

commit_message:
Remove duplicated fake drivers

We don't need to have several fake drivers like FakeISCSIDriver. Let's
leave only one copy of each in tests directory. They could be used for
unit, functional and integrational tests as well.

Change-Id: I45f852544ff9ca9d4ab50546e036afb4f1e31904

commit_message:
Relocates cli options registration from bootstrap to server

This fixes an issue (see rhbz#1333884) where using the tempest
CLI results in the error 'Could not load 'zaqar_tests':
arguments already parsed: cannot register CLI option'. Moving the
cli options registration to cmd.server resolves this problem.

Includes followups:
Fix config parsing in zaqar-server
(cherry picked from commit 7c6eecdb4f7a0cd2684c2fdbedfc17ba24ce72d8)
Fix debug log missing issue
(cherry picked from commit 95c9c5da9545b0bdb2be9bcb08b393a28bdf2382)

Change-Id: I56779da783261c6eba07a7d9286d1615dcff3598
(cherry picked from commit e439b2e9ce2d97791e59698303c86ca2f0feccab)

subject: Add 'level playing field' requirement
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-06-14 13:35:23.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/governance/commit/04380845eb3ff8185f5449a942dd99d8141e471a', 'message': 'Add 'level playing field' requirement

From an upstream perspective, I see us as being in the business
of providing open collaboration playing fields in order to build
projects to reach the OpenStack Mission. We collectively provide
resources (infra, horizontal teams, events...) in order to enable
that open collaboration.

An important characteristic of these open collaboration grounds
is that they need to be a level playing field, where no specific
organization is being given an unfair advantage. I expect the teams
that we bless as "official" project teams to operate in that fair
manner. Otherwise we end up blessing what is essentially a trojan
horse for a given organization, open-washing their project in the
process. Such a project can totally exist as an unofficial project
(and even be developed on OpenStack infrastructure) but I don't
think it should be given free space in our Design Summits or
benefit from "OpenStack community" branding.

So if, in a given project team, developers from one specific
organization benefit from access to specific knowledge or hardware
(think 3rd-party testing blackboxes that decide if a patch goes in,
or access to proprietary hardware or software that the open source
code primarily interfaces with), then this project team should be
rejected under the "open community" rule.

Change-Id: I0cd689afb8ddb7a269b9ce378e4c6647652f6977
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2016-06-17 12:15:10.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/governance/commit/0b24613b68fbcdf00759f75b6ed0cb935a5adcc0', 'message': 'Add 'level playing field' requirement

process. Such a project can totally exist as an unofficial project
(and even be developed on OpenStack infrastructure) but I don't
think it should be given free space in our Design Summits or
benefit from "OpenStack community" branding.

So if, in a given project team, developers from one specific
organization benefit from access to specific knowledge or hardware
(think exclusive access to proprietary hardware or software that
the open source code primarily interfaces with), then this project
team should be rejected under the "open community" rule.

This requirement (like all requirements in this document) is meant
to be interpreted by humans on a case-by-case basis. In particular,
there is a grey area around drivers for proprietary solutions that
requires human judgment here. As a rule of thumb, if the open
implementation was unusable open core bait to lure people into
using the one and only proprietary driver, it would be a problem.
If the open implementation was fully functional and nothing
prevented adding additional proprietary drivers to the code base,
there would be no problem.

commit_message:
Add 'level playing field' requirement

From an upstream perspective, I see us as being in the business
of providing open collaboration playing fields in order to build
projects to reach the OpenStack Mission. We collectively provide
resources (infra, horizontal teams, events...) in order to enable
that open collaboration.

An important characteristic of these open collaboration grounds
is that they need to be a level playing field, where no specific
organization is being given an unfair advantage. I expect the teams
that we bless as "official" project teams to operate in that fair
manner. Otherwise we end up blessing what is essentially a trojan
horse for a given organization, open-washing their project in the
process. Such a project can totally exist as an unofficial project
(and even be developed on OpenStack infrastructure) but I don't
think it should be given free space in our Design Summits or
benefit from "OpenStack community" branding.

So if, in a given project team, developers from one specific
organization benefit from access to specific knowledge or hardware
(think exclusive access to proprietary hardware or software that
the open source code primarily interfaces with), then this project
team should be rejected under the "open community" rule.

This requirement (like all requirements in this document) is meant
to be interpreted by humans on a case-by-case basis. In particular,
there is a grey area around drivers for proprietary solutions that
requires human judgment here. As a rule of thumb, if the open
implementation was unusable open core bait to lure people into
using the one and only proprietary driver, it would be a problem.
If the open implementation was fully functional and nothing
prevented adding additional proprietary drivers to the code base,
there would be no problem.

Change-Id: I0cd689afb8ddb7a269b9ce378e4c6647652f6977
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/governance refs/changes/48/329448/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: * The project provides a level open collaboration playing field. Developers from a given organization do not have an unfair advantage compared to others, due to specific access to resources or proprietary technology.

commit_message:
Update stable API doc to indicate code removal

V2 API is totally removed, we can update document to tell this
to reader, keep this document might be helpful to some users
who are new to V2.1(legacy)/V2.1 concept.

Partially implements blueprint remove-legacy-v2-api-code

Change-Id: Idb67a34d89acaeb3f87ffb7e6c35f2a171a3fc76

subject: [WIP] OVS trunk bridge plugging for vlan-aware VMs
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-05-25 21:52:07.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/7270e803b18740a4b5cf544a92a9f3b6b78a5d56', 'message': "[WIP] OVS trunk bridge plugging for vlan-aware VMs

In order to provide vlan-aware VM functionality within the Neutron OVS
agent (in a way that would also be compatible with OVS-DPDK), an
instance's tap device needs to be attached to an OVS bridge that is then
connected into the OVS integration bridge using a patch port pair.

This is very similar to the current way that ovs_hybrid plugging works
today, except:
1) Nova creates an OVS bridge instead of a linux bridge (i.e. qbr) to
   attach the tap interface to.
2) Nova connects that bridge to the OVS integration bridge using a patch
   port pair instead of a veth pair.

By using an OVS bridge instead of a linux bridge as the tap interface
attach point, Neutron will be able to create further patch port pairs
between the trunk bridge and the integration bridge with specific vlan
tags used to mux/demux vlan-tagged traffic to/from the VM and thereby
implement vlan-aware VMs functionality.

This patch only provides the initial plugging-related methods for VIFs
of the type ovs_trunk. Further dependent patches will drive the logic of
how these methods are actually called, based upon details in the VIF
object.

Change-Id: Ic43e5b539afb14b6682103a37ec58a5745d2ab01
Partially-implements: blueprint vlan-aware-vms

1) Nova creates an OVS bridge instead of a linux bridge (i.e. qbr) to
   attach the tap interface to.
2) Nova connects that bridge to the OVS integration bridge using a patch
   port pair instead of a veth pair.

By using an OVS bridge instead of a linux bridge as the tap interface
attach point, Neutron will be able to create additional patch port pairs
between the trunk bridge and the integration bridge with specific vlan
tags used to mux/demux vlan-tagged traffic to/from the VM and thereby
implement vlan-aware VMs functionality.

The responsibility of creating the OVS "trunk" bridge and connecting it
to the integration bridge via patch ports is left to Nova rather than
Neutron because it simplifies the overall work flow between
Nova/Neutron, similar to the reason why Nova is responsible for creating
the Linux bridge and veth pair in the ovs_hybrid strategy.

NOTE: as Nova is currently working towards integration with the os-vif
library (https://review.openstack.org/#/c/269672/), this patch (and

but feel free to add feedback to this patch (and follow-ups) until it's

commit_message:
[WIP] OVS trunk bridge plugging for vlan-aware VMs

In order to provide vlan-aware VM functionality within the Neutron OVS
agent (in a way that would also be compatible with OVS-DPDK), an
instance's tap device needs to be attached to an OVS "trunk" bridge that
is then connected into the OVS integration bridge using a patch port
pair.

This is very similar to the current way that ovs_hybrid plugging works
today, except:
1) Nova creates an OVS bridge instead of a linux bridge (i.e. qbr) to
   attach the tap interface to.
2) Nova connects that bridge to the OVS integration bridge using a patch
   port pair instead of a veth pair.

By using an OVS bridge instead of a linux bridge as the tap interface
attach point, Neutron will be able to create additional patch port pairs
between the trunk bridge and the integration bridge with specific vlan
tags used to mux/demux vlan-tagged traffic to/from the VM and thereby
implement vlan-aware VMs functionality.

The responsibility of creating the OVS "trunk" bridge and connecting it
to the integration bridge via patch ports is left to Nova rather than
Neutron because it simplifies the overall work flow between
Nova/Neutron, similar to the reason why Nova is responsible for creating
the Linux bridge and veth pair in the ovs_hybrid strategy.

NOTE: as Nova is currently working towards integration with the os-vif
library (https://review.openstack.org/#/c/269672/), this patch (and
follow-ups) will most likely be merged to os-vif rather than Nova,
but feel free to add feedback to this patch (and follow-ups) until it's
ported to os-vif.

This patch only provides the initial plugging-related methods for VIFs
of the type ovs_trunk. Further dependent patches will drive the logic of
how these methods are actually called, based upon details in the VIF
object.

Change-Id: Ic43e5b539afb14b6682103a37ec58a5745d2ab01
Partially-implements: blueprint vlan-aware-vms
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/53/321253/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def create_ovs_bridge(bridge): cmd = ['--', '--may-exist', 'add-br', bridge] _ovs_vsctl(cmd) def create_ovs_patch_port_pair(br1, br2, patch1, patch2, iface_id, mac, instance_id): cmd = ['--', '--if-exists', 'del-port', patch1, '--', '--if-exists', 'del-port', patch2, '--', 'add-port', br1, patch1, '--', 'add-port', br2, patch2, '--', 'set', 'Interface', patch1, 'type=patch', 'options:peer=%s' % patch2, '--', 'set', 'Interface', patch2, 'type=patch', 'options:peer=%s' % patch1, 'external-ids:iface-id=%s' % iface_id, 'external-ids:iface-status=active', 'external-ids:attached-mac=%s' % mac, 'external-ids:vm-uuid=%s' % instance_id] _ovs_vsctl(cmd)

commit_message:
[WIP] Add logic around OVS trunk port plugging

This patch provides the logic to differentiate between OVS trunk ports
and other types of OVS ports in order to call the correct plug_*,
unplug_*, and get_config_* methods.

NOTE: as mentioned in the parent patch, Nova is currently working
towards integrating the os-vif library, so this patch (and follow-ups)
would most likely end up merging into os-vif rather than Nova. Feel free
to leave feedback on this patch anyways.

Partially-implements: blueprint vlan-aware-vms
Change-Id: Iac2a3283a5bb68cc313c5deda61d4d31fabc0fac
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/61/321261/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: VIF_DETAILS_OVS_TRUNK = 'ovs_trunk' def is_trunk_port(self): # TODO: make this default to False before this is finalized return self['details'].get(VIF_DETAILS_OVS_TRUNK, True)

commit_message:
[WIP] Trunk bridge plugging - OVS-DPDK vhost-user

This patch builds upon the OVS trunk bridge plugging provided in an
earlier patch for VIF_TYPE_OVS to provide similar functionality for
VIF_TYPE_VHOSTUSER (for OVS-DPDK).

The vhost-user vif will be attached to the OVS trunk bridge that
is connected to the OVS integration bridge via a patch port pair.

This patch only provides the initial plugging-related method
implementations; a follow-on patch will provide the logic around how a
VIF is determined to be a vhost-user trunk in order to call the
appropriate plug methods.

NOTE: as mentioned in the parent patch, Nova is currently working
towards integration of the os-vif library, so this patch would likely
merge in os-vif rather than in Nova. Feel free to leave feedback on this
patch anyways.

Change-Id: Ie6d95cb9d3a3cc715c30b9a11c90d1987c2031be
Partially-implements: blueprint vlan-aware-vms
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/13/321813/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def plug_vhostuser_ovs_trunk(self, instance, vif): """Plug the ovs trunk bridge, and plug a VIF_TYPE_VHOSTUSER into the trunk bridge """ self.plug_ovs_trunk(instance, vif) trunk_br_name = self.get_trunk_br_name(vif['id']) self._plug_vhostuser_ovs(instance, vif, trunk_br_name) def _plug_vhostuser_ovs(self, instance, vif, bridge): bridge, def plug_vhostuser_ovs(self, instance, vif): """Plug a VIF_TYPE_VHOSTUSER into an ovs bridge""" br_name = self.get_bridge_name(vif) self._plug_vhostuser_ovs(instance, vif, br_name) def _unplug_vhostuser_ovs(self, instance, vif, bridge): linux_net.delete_ovs_vif_port(bridge, port_name) def unplug_vhostuser_ovs(self, instance, vif): """Unplug a VIF_TYPE_VHOSTUSER from an ovs bridge""" br_name = self.get_bridge_name(vif) self._unplug_vhostuser_ovs(instance, vif, br_name) def unplug_vhostuser_ovs_trunk(self, instance, vif): """Unplug a VIF_TYPE_VHOSTUSER from an ovs trunk bridge""" trunk_br_name = self.get_trunk_br_name(vif['id']) self._unplug_vhostuser_ovs(instance, vif, trunk_br_name) self.unplug_ovs_trunk(instance, vif)
deleted_lines: def plug_vhostuser_ovs(self, instance, vif): """Plug a VIF_TYPE_VHOSTUSER into an ovs bridge""" self.get_bridge_name(vif), def unplug_vhostuser_ovs(self, instance, vif): """Unplug a VIF_TYPE_VHOSTUSER into an ovs bridge""" linux_net.delete_ovs_vif_port(self.get_bridge_name(vif), port_name)

commit_message:
[WIP] Add logic around OVS-DPDK vhost-user trunk bridge plugging

When a vif is found to be an OVS-DPDK vhost-user trunk port, use the
corresponding plug_* and unplug_* methods to plug the vif using the OVS
trunk bridge strategy.

NOTE: as mentioned in the parent patch, Nova is currently working
towards integration of the os-vif library, so this patch would likely
merge in os-vif rather than in Nova. Feel free to leave feedback on this
patch anyways.

Partially-implements: blueprint vlan-aware-vms
Change-Id: I757a3fbebbc6abf085020afc97efcd5188326b34
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/23/321823/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Specifies whether vhost-user socket should be plugged into ovs bridge # using the ovs_trunk strategy. Valid values are True and False VIF_DETAILS_VHOSTUSER_OVS_TRUNK_PLUG = 'vhostuser_ovs_trunk_plug'

commit_message:
Add 'type:horizon-plugin' tag

Define a new deliverable type tag to describe deliverables that
are specifically meant to be loaded by Horizon to provide UI for
a given project.

Change-Id: If1adb5d30d215cf17e6bf72a46c8bbc33561d703
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/governance refs/changes/79/329479/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: :: This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode .. _`tag-type:horizon-plugin`: ===================== type:horizon-plugin ===================== This tag is part of the type-classification system for projects managed by the release team. ``type:horizon-plugin`` indicates that a deliverable is meant to be consumed by Horizon as a plug-in, to provide an integrated web UI for a given project. Application to current projects =============================== .. tagged-projects:: type:horizon-plugin Rationale ========= On the releases publication website there are a number of deliverables that do not qualify to be a service or a library. Some of those are really corner cases, but a lot of them happen to be Horizon plugins, using a combination of 'ui' or 'dashboard' or 'horizon' prefixes or suffixes. Using this tag will help users quickly identify which deliverables provide this companion functionality, and to display them in their own category on the releases publication website. Requirements ============ * The repository contains code meant to be dynamically loaded by OpenStack Horizon to provide UI to specific projects. Tag application process ======================= Anyone may propose adding or removing this tag to a set of projects by proposing a change to the openstack/governance repository. The change is reviewed by the Release Team and Technical Committee and approved using standard resolution approval rules, including discussion at at least one Technical Committee public IRC meeting. Deprecation =========== There is no deprecation process for tags in the ``type`` namespace. If we need to change the type of a project, we can just do that.

subject: Allow Neutron deployment without overlay
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-06-21 20:15:59.000000000', 'files': ['playbooks/os-neutron-install.yml'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible/commit/8568dcdd6202ddfd18087f5f09c2ddf87525463a', 'message': "Allow Neutron deployment without overlay

Without an overlay network enabled, the Neutron play will fail to set
_local_ip due to _overlay_network being an empty dict.

Example:
TASK: [set local_ip fact (is_metal)] ******************************************
fatal: [aio1] => One or more undefined variables: 'dict object' has no attribute 'bridge'

An undefined overlay network is appropriate for deployments where an
overlay network is not used or supported by the selected Neutron plugin.

The Neutron playbook will now accommodate this deployment scenario
without a hard failure due to the undefined variable.

Change-Id: I425615ffb8303230ab1e48cfa3549e20802e0031
"}]
commit_message:
Allow Neutron deployment without overlay

Without an overlay network enabled, the Neutron play will fail to set
_local_ip due to _overlay_network being an empty dict.

Example:
TASK: [set local_ip fact (is_metal)] ******************************************
fatal: [aio1] => One or more undefined variables: 'dict object' has no attribute 'bridge'

An undefined overlay network is appropriate for deployments where an
overlay network is not used or supported by the selected Neutron plugin.

The Neutron playbook will now accommodate this deployment scenario
without a hard failure due to the undefined variable.

Change-Id: I425615ffb8303230ab1e48cfa3549e20802e0031
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible refs/changes/62/332462/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: - _overlay_network.bridge is defined

commit_message:
Remove the TODO file

The problem with TODO files is they require constant commits to keep
up to date, and this rarely happens. As is the case here where this
file is now quite stale and hasn't ever been updated. This commit
just drops the file in favor of just using launchpad as our task
tracking solution.

Change-Id: Id576d0f4dab2ecaf28db93909b7860306898a759
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/os-testr refs/changes/57/328357/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Port last test (test_secrets) to Python 3

* normalize_before_encryption(): on Python 3, unencrypted is already a Unicode
  string (no need to decode).
* test_secrets: don't pass bytes string but native string (py2: bytes,
  py3: Unicode) as payload
* test_secrets: Decode HTTP bytes from UTF-8 for comparison
* test_get_secret_is_decoded_for_binary(): expect a binary string,
  not a Unicode string
* test_secrets: replace map() with a reglar loop (for) to execute
  child.delete() on Python 3. On Python 3, map() is now lazy and only
  execute the expression when the map is consumed.
* Remove tests-py3-blacklist.txt and the testenv:py34 section from
  tox.ini since all unit tests now pass on Python 3.4

Partially implements: blueprint barbican-py3
Change-Id: Ief8531c3b7201f884d5d4ca7a47a381d0bb9cb2c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/barbican refs/changes/27/329427/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

subject: Volume delete parameters
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-05-23 16:46:41.000000000', 'files': ['specs/newton/delete-parameters.rst'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder-specs/commit/fad493c27c72938da459425fdac5613cd6d73340', 'message': 'Volume delete parameters

Handle combinations of "cascade" and "force"
for delete operations.

APIImpact: New volume delete params

Change-Id: Ie57a3d5cc525830b99717e73aba7267a0592c3ca
'}]
commit_message:
Volume delete parameters

Handle combinations of "cascade" and "force"
for delete operations.

APIImpact: New volume delete params

Change-Id: Ie57a3d5cc525830b99717e73aba7267a0592c3ca
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder-specs refs/changes/52/320052/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode =================================================== Parameter combinations for delete (vol, snap, etc.) =================================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/cinder/+spec/volume-delete-parameters This spec outlines how to improve our volume delete functionality with regards to optional parameters which request non-default behaviors. Problem description =================== It is not possible to combine both volume force delete and cascade delete. It is also difficult to add more parameters to volume delete, since they have to interact in a reasonable way with things like os-force-delete, which is part of volume delete from a user's point of view, but not the same API action. Use Cases ========= This makes it easier to delete a volume which may be in an odd state. It also simplifies our API by passing optional parameters to delete rather than separate action calls. This allows us to combine the parameters in meaningful ways (force + cascade), as well as extend the same combinations to snapshot-delete, cg-delete, etc., without having to make X delete API actions for each parameter. (eg. os-force-delete, os-force-delete-snapshot, os-force-delete-cg, etc.) Also consider if we wish to add the option later to delete an attached volume with a "force-detach" parameter, etc. This also should reduce the number of cases where an admin/user needs to use reset-state operations. Proposed change =============== Deprecate use of os-force-delete and make "force" a parameter passed to volume delete like "cascade" is. The ability to default "force" to be an admin-only operation via config will be maintained. Alternatives ------------ Change nothing. Data model impact ----------------- None REST API impact --------------- * New boolean "force" parameter for volume delete, which defaults to False. This will behave the same as os-force-delete if not combined with other arguments. If combined with cascade, a cascade delete which ignores the volume and snapshot states will be performed. Security impact --------------- None Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- $ cinder delete --force --cascade <volume> will be accepted. This gives a "delete this volume regardless of the state of things" operation which does not exist today. Performance Impact ------------------ None Other deployer impact --------------------- None Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: eharney Work Items ---------- * Add "force" as a parameter to volume delete API * Add logic to handle combination of force and cascade * (eventually) remove os-force-delete with a new API microversion * Look at what to do, if anything, in this same regard for "unmanage", e.g., "unmanage --cascade". Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= New tempest test for volume delete which uses the parameterized version rather than os-force-delete. Tempest test for cascade + force volume delete. Documentation Impact ==================== New arguments for cinderclient volume delete. References ========== * Cascade delete https://review.openstack.org/#/c/201748/

commit_message:
Add "--project" option to the "flavor create" command.

Add ``--project`` and ``--project-domain`` options to the
``flavor create`` command. We can use these options to add
the flavor access to a givin project when we create the flavor.

Change-Id: Ic1907272c1d1ae526f9c9e86f32ba06c6da147c0
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-openstackclient refs/changes/90/329790/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: --- features: - Add ``--project`` and ``--project-domain`` options to the ``flavor create`` command. We can use these options to add the flavor access to a givin project when we create the flavor.

commit_message:
Add openstack-neutron-sriov-nic-agent package in overcloud image

In SR-IOV enabled compute nodes, sriov-agent allows admin to
control the port states and security. This patch enables the
addition of the sriov-agent package in the overcloud image.

Implements: blueprint tripleo-sriov

Change-Id: I83f12627b3b2d7486d7f15ebcd5a7dd49a2fd8df
Signed-off-by: Saravanan KR <skramaja@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Add release note for policy_rcd provider

Change Ic54b9707b6ef36032d71fe9dc04a7e310293f127 missed release note,
so this patch adds it.

Alos improve unit test for policy-rcd provider.

Change-Id: Ie6d4dd1e5406acd097969a9ff7fccd5dfa7f8632
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-openstacklib refs/changes/35/332035/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines:
describe '#exists?' do it 'should exists on Debian family' do provider.stubs(:check_os).returns(true) file = mock('file') file_content = "# THIS FILE MANAGED BY PUPPET
#!/bin/bash
[[ "$1" == "service" ]] && exit 101
" provider.stubs(:policy_rcd).returns(file) provider.stubs(:check_policy_rcd).returns(true) provider.stubs(:file_lines).returns(file_content.split("
")) expect(provider.exists?).to be_truthy end it 'should not exists on Debian family when file is present' do provider.stubs(:check_os).returns(true) file = mock('file') file_content = "# THIS FILE MANAGED BY PUPPET
#!/bin/bash
[[ "$1" == "new-service" ]] && exit 101
" provider.stubs(:policy_rcd).returns(file) provider.stubs(:check_policy_rcd).returns(true) provider.stubs(:file_lines).returns(file_content.split("
")) expect(provider.exists?).to be_falsey end it 'should not exists on Debian family when file is not present' do provider.stubs(:check_os).returns(true) provider.stubs(:check_policy_rcd).returns(false) expect(provider.exists?).to be_falsey end it 'should exists on non-Debian family' do provider.stubs(:check_os).returns(false) expect(provider.exists?).to be_truthy end end describe 'write_to_file' do it 'should write to file' do file = mock policy = mock content = 'some_content' File.expects(:open).with(file, 'a+').returns(policy) policy.expects(:puts).with(content) policy.expects(:close) provider.class.write_to_file(file, content) end it 'should truncate file' do file = mock policy = mock content = 'some_content' File.expects(:truncate).with(file, 0) File.expects(:open).with(file, 'a+').returns(policy) policy.expects(:puts).with(content) policy.expects(:close) provider.class.write_to_file(file, content, true) end end

commit_message:
Add current house rules for reference

This lists exceptions to the formal votes for various changes
in the openstack/governance repository. It corresponds to
house rules as they were proposed to the Newton membership in
our introductory meeting[1], with additional wording to cover
the exceptions proposed by Doug Hellmann at our last meeting[2].

[1]
http://eavesdrop.openstack.org/meetings/tc/2016/tc.2016-04-12-20.01.log.html#l-17
[2]
http://eavesdrop.openstack.org/meetings/tc/2016/tc.2016-06-14-20.01.log.html#l-33

Change-Id: I39a92a18a08ea851deab2c5686d30631be33ae26
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/governance refs/changes/42/330442/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: ============================================= House rules for governance changes approval ============================================= While most of the governance changes call for a formal discussion and vote by the Technical Committee membership, we also have a number of exceptions to that general rule, in order to speed up the processing of smaller changes. This document lists those "house rules" for reference. Typo fixes ---------- When the change fixes content that is obviously wrong (updates a PTL email address, fixes a typo...) then the chair is allowed to directly approve them. Code changes ------------ The `openstack/governance` repository also contains code to build and publish pages on the governance.openstack.org website. For those we apply the normal code review rules (with RollCall votes being considered +-2): change will be approved once 2 `RollCall+1` (other than the change owner) are posted (and no `RollCall-1`). Delegated tags -------------- Some tags are delegated to a specific team, like :ref:`tag-stable:follows-policy`, :ref:`tag-release:cycle-with-intermediary` or :ref:`tag-vulnerability:managed`. Those need to get approved by the corresponding team PTL, and can be directly approved by the chair once this approval is given. Other project team updates -------------------------- For other changes within an existing project team, like addition of a new git repository or self-assertion of a tag, we use lazy consensus. If there is no objection posted one week after the change is proposed (or a significant new revision of the change is posted), then the change can be approved by the chair. One exception to this would be significant team mission statement changes, which should be approved by a formal vote after an in-meeting discussion. In corner cases where the change is time-sensitive (like a deliverable reorganization which blocks a release request), the chair may fast-track the change, but should report on that exception at the next TC meeting. Rolling back fast-tracked changes --------------------------------- As a safety net, if any member disagrees with any change that was fast-tracked under one of those house rules, that member can propose a revert of the change. Such revert should be directly approved by the chair and the change be put on the agenda of the next TC meeting for further discussion.

commit_message:
Add full-deploy-with-scale script

- Testing periodic gate
- Related change: https://review.gerrithub.io/#/c/281291/

Change-Id: Ib7a30afad98b039415bec97c6aaea50ec5fe6156
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-quickstart refs/changes/46/330146/8 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: #!/bin/bash # CI test that does a full deploy, scales a compute node, and validates # the overcloud for both promote and gate jobs # Usage: full-deploy-with-scale.sh <release> <build_system> <config> <job_type> set -eux RELEASE=$1 BUILD_SYS=$2 CONFIG=$3 JOB_TYPE=$4 if [ "$JOB_TYPE" = "gate" ] || [ "$JOB_TYPE" = "periodic" ]; then LOCATION='stable' elif [ "$JOB_TYPE" = "promote" ]; then LOCATION='testing' else echo "Job type must be one of gate, periodic, or promote" exit 1 fi # (trown) This is so that we ensure separate ssh sockets for # concurrent jobs. Without this, two jobs running in parallel # would try to use the same undercloud-stack socket. socketdir=$(mktemp -d /tmp/sockXXXXXX) export ANSIBLE_SSH_CONTROL_PATH=$socketdir/%%h-%%r pushd $WORKSPACE/tripleo-quickstart # run scale phase 1 against the gate job: Scale new compute node -> Delete original compute node bash $WORKSPACE/tripleo-quickstart/quickstart.sh \ --working-dir $WORKSPACE/ \ --retain-inventory \ --requirements $WORKSPACE/tripleo-quickstart/quickstart-role-requirements.txt \ -e undercloud_image_url="http://artifacts.ci.centos.org/artifacts/rdo/images/$RELEASE/$BUILD_SYS/$LOCATION/undercloud.qcow2" \ --config $WORKSPACE/config/general_config/$CONFIG.yml \ --tags all \ --playbook scale_nodes.yml \ $VIRTHOST $RELEASE # run scale phase 2 against the gate job: Re-inventory overcloud -> Validate # Note(hrybacki): The reason we need seperate playbook execution: During scale we create # one /additional/ compute node and then delete the /original/ compute node. # The deleted node is still in memory and subsequently will cause issues # while re-inventorying and validating the overcloud bash $WORKSPACE/tripleo-quickstart/quickstart.sh \ --working-dir $WORKSPACE/ \ --retain-inventory \ --requirements $WORKSPACE/tripleo-quickstart/quickstart-role-requirements.txt \ -e undercloud_image_url="http://artifacts.ci.centos.org/artifacts/rdo/images/$RELEASE/$BUILD_SYS/$LOCATION/undercloud.qcow2" \ --config $WORKSPACE/config/general_config/$CONFIG.yml \ --tags all \ --playbook scale_nodes_verify.yml \ $VIRTHOST $RELEASE fi popd

commit_message:
Volume connection information for Ironic nodes

This spec defines data model and REST APIs for boot from volume
support in Ironic.

Co-Authored-By: Ramakrishnan G <rameshg87@gmail.com>
Change-Id: Ibf50be735905f868e0d523ab16353a6b5cc300af
Partial-Bug: 1526231
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic-specs refs/changes/96/200496/23 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ======================================================= Add attributes about volume connection into nodes table ======================================================= https://blueprints.launchpad.net/ironic/+spec/template This blueprint adds two new attributes 'volume_initiator_info' and 'volume_target_info' to node table. With this feature, Nova can get initiator information of a bare metal node and ask Cinder to connect a volume to the node. Problem description =================== When user starts bare metal instance with cinder volume, nova orchestrates the communication with Cinder and Ironic. The work flow in boot process is like following: * User asks Nova to boot a node with a cinder volume * Nova calls ironic to collect iSCSI/FC initiator information -(a) * Ironic collect initiator information and return it to Nova * Nova calls Cinder to attach the volume to the node * Cinder attaches the volume to the node and returns connection information which includes target information * Nova calls Ironic to set target information -(b) * Nova calls Ironic to spawn a instance * If the node boots from volume, Ironic asks BIOS to boot from SAN * Ironic turns on the node In the work flow above, Nova calls Ironic to get/set initiator/target information ((a) and (b)) but currently Ironic has neither those information nor APIs for them. Proposed change =============== * Add a new attribute `volume_initiator_info` in nodes table. This attribute contains iSCSI/FC initiator information like following: * wwnn (list of world wide node names for the initiator) * wwpn (list of world wide port names for the initiator) * iqn * ip (for iSCSI initiator port) * Add a new attribute `volume_target_info` in nodes table. This attribute contains iSCSI/FC target information like following: * target_iqn * target_lun * target_portal * ip * port * auth_method * auth_username * auth_password * target_wwn Alternatives ------------ Saving these informations in a new table named volume_connection_info and adding new API to set/get those informations. Data model impact ----------------- Add two new attributes `volume_initiator_info` and `volume_target_info` in `node` table. Those field are json dict. State Machine Impact -------------------- None. REST API impact --------------- Two new attributes `volume_initiator_info` and `volume_target_info` will be added to the Node resource. Client (CLI) impact ------------------- None. RPC API impact -------------- None. Driver API impact ----------------- None. Nova driver impact ------------------ When preparing the node with cinder volume, the Nova driver gets initiator information from node resources. In addition to that, the Nova driver updates volume target information which Cinder returns when it spawns an instance. Security impact --------------- None. Other end user impact --------------------- None. Scalability impact ------------------ None. Performance Impact ------------------ This may extend the time required for nova boot/delete, but it's not a big impact and it's important for enterprise users. Other deployer impact --------------------- The following initiator fields are required while enrolling node into ironic: * iSCSI: * ip * iqn * FC: * wwnn * wwpn Developer impact ---------------- jroll proposed "Ironic: block storage support"[1]_ for nova ironic driver and that is meant for in-band use. The solution this spec proposes can be used for both in-band and out-of-band control basically, but need some updates for in-band use, e.g. where/how to create iqn etc. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: satoru-moriya-br Other contributors: None Work Items ---------- * Create `volume_initiator_info` and `volume_target_info` field in the nodes table in the database. * Create new attributes `volume_initiator_info` and `volume_target_info` in the Node object. Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= * unit tests will be added/updated to cover the changes. * Tempest tests will be added to Ironic to ensure that the new /nodes/<uuid>/initiator and /nodes/<uuid>/target is working properly. Upgrades and Backwards Compatibility ==================================== Add a migration script for DB. Documentation Impact ==================== Developer documentation should be updated to explain new interface. References ========== .. [1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/184652/ .. [2] https://blueprints.launchpad.net/ironic/+spec/cinder-integration .. [3] https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Ironic/blueprints/cinder-integration

subject: Add value format validations
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-06-20 19:33:09.000000000', 'files': ['instack_undercloud/validator.py', 'instack_undercloud/tests/test_validator.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/instack-undercloud/commit/c6adebec47f35d6c7d9e1a2a99314606287d1a1d', 'message': 'Add value format validations

There are circumstances where an opt may be set to a legal value
that will error in non-obvious ways.  Two of these are setting
local_ip to a non-CIDR-ish value which returns a cryptic netaddr
error, and using a non-FQDN for the undercloud hostname which will
cause failures later in the install.

This change adds validations to catch both of these cases.

Change-Id: Ied9b5ffaff18e2a405443a00b35ca53735c46024
'}]
commit_message:
Add value format validations

There are circumstances where an opt may be set to a legal value
that will error in non-obvious ways.  Two of these are setting
local_ip to a non-CIDR-ish value which returns a cryptic netaddr
error, and using a non-FQDN for the undercloud hostname which will
cause failures later in the install.

This change adds validations to catch both of these cases.

Change-Id: Ied9b5ffaff18e2a405443a00b35ca53735c46024
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/instack-undercloud refs/changes/17/331817/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def test_fail_on_invalid_local_ip(self): self.conf.config(local_ip='192.0.2.1') self.assertRaises(validator.FailedValidation, undercloud._validate_network) def test_fail_on_unqualified_hostname(self): self.conf.config(undercloud_hostname='undercloud') self.assertRaises(validator.FailedValidation, undercloud._validate_network)

added_lines: # Copyright 2016 Intel Corporation # Copyright 2014 Rackspace, Inc. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. commit_message:
Remove the nova.compute.resources entrypoint

This was the entrypoint namespace for
compute resources which was deprecated in mitaka
under 649decbaadb1064448ae0a6d25be30fab2451bb4
and removed in newton 49d9433c62d74f6ebdcf0832e3a03e544b1d6c83
so we should also remove the entrypoint.

Change-Id: Idaed7291ab6c3ab122edabfd3d614f42d469a34f

subject: Bump default deploy timeout to 90 minutes
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-06-21 18:31:22.000000000', 'files': ['roles/tripleo/overcloud/defaults/main.yml'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-quickstart/commit/da93a0f0f6c8898c521f5ee222c27972c1d90a3d', 'message': 'Bump default deploy timeout to 90 minutes

We have started hitting the deploy timeout pretty regularly in the
HA jobs. Hopefully once we have composable roles, we can split the
jobs up to provide full coverage across multiple jobs while
lowering the footprint of the individual jobs. In the meantime, we
are at the mercy of the monolithic roles, and when more stuff is

Change-Id: I4deeb5b4efff768d1e4f8d74b8eee055c151f4a5
'}]
commit_message:
Bump default deploy timeout to 90 minutes

We have started hitting the deploy timeout pretty regularly in the
HA jobs. Hopefully once we have composable roles, we can split the
jobs up to provide full coverage across multiple jobs while
lowering the footprint of the individual jobs. In the meantime, we
are at the mercy of the monolithic roles, and when more stuff is
added the deploy time will increase.

Change-Id: I4deeb5b4efff768d1e4f8d74b8eee055c151f4a5
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-quickstart refs/changes/21/332421/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
[zmq] Fix message sending when using proxy and not using PUB/SUB

This patch fixes the problem of sending messages in the following
configuration: use_router_proxy=True and use_pub_sub=False. Right
now we have incorrect both cast and fanout messages: cast acts as
fanout (instead of round-robin) and fanout duplicate each message
twice.

Change-Id: I2b039aa462ddde300fd50b3754e4fe66abf6e635
